comments.commentBody:
The rest of you:

Trump should divest himself of the stock he has in the company at question. I imagine that it's run up rather much since last month's election, so he made a pretty intelligent investment; but we don't prohibit people from being elected president because they buy and sell stock.

As to the environment, we need a sensible national energy plan, that we've never had. Trump hasn't yet named an Energy Sec., and that department deals more with nuclear proliferation than anything else, but I hope that TRUMP'S Energy Dept. FNALLY will define an actionable plan that allows us to provide for a manageable transition to less polluting forms of energy. However, for the time being, the U.S. already does more in this vein than almost anyone else and at immense expense, it doesn't seem to be saving the coral, and the growing energy needs of the world over the next generation won't be met by windmills.

Maybe Russia might consider drilling less oil and gas and building fewer pipelines. Here, we need jobs and energy.

As we are beginning to see, Trump does not laugh, smile or make funny comments. He has demanded that SNL "Retire" its recent skit. He was upset about the incident at the Hamilton Play. He has even sued the writer of his biography that he gave an interview to.

He has commented of tweeted that is is wrong to criticize the president, or make fun of him, he is as many have observed, a narcissist. He can not stand being made fun of, and calls any criticism of him unfair. He has a fractured ego, it is the personality of a schoolyard bully. The best way we have to keep him in check is to make fun of him constantly, he will crack.

But watching him reveals more than just a narcissist. He has swindled workers, contractors, and investors, claims it is just good business, he does not distinguish between right and wrong, between moral and immoral, he has no conscience, it is the personality of a sociopath. It is easy to believe he would have you killed if he thought he could get away with it.

Watch him speak to his crowds, his facial expressions, it is like facing Dirty Harry, he wants to intimidate his viewers, not convince them. His followers respond in kind, letting you know they like intimidating you, not leading you telling you what he is going to do, not what you should do or why.

Yes he speaks , acts , gestures like, a Fascist, just like those preceding him, and his followers like it that way. We have to laugh him away, he will try to retaliate with force.
Hopefully, he will "crack" before,he gets,the nuke codes. I am not optimistic.
Don't equate Dirty Harry with Donald Trump. Dirty Harry is not a buffoon, Donald Trump is.

b fagan 3 Dec post

Dear Mr. fagan,

You recommend patience with regulations for drones.

Perhaps you are not aware that the FAA was SEVEN YEARS LATE in issuing the "line-of-sight" regulations it has finally disgorged.

"good things take time" you say.

Forgive me if I doubt that, based on current history here in the US, good things will happen at all.

I have had better luck in Europe getting permission to use UAV's for inspections. In Norway, for example, UAV's can be used to inspect unmanned offshore oil and gas platforms out in the North Sea.

For heaven's sake, Europe is not exactly a risk-prone regulatory environment. Nor is their airspace one whit less constricted than ours. Quite the contrary.

A golden opportunity to REDUCE risk to workers and to the public at large is being squandered.

Regardless of Trump's viewpoint as President or as President-elect, he conceded that he had money invested in the pipeline, which constitutes an inherent conflict of interest in this particular matter.

He cannot continue throughout his Presidency like this. He must divest himself of all of his investments and put the funds therefrom into a blind trust, run by an unrelated third party. He is no different, no better nor worse than any one of the rest of us, the people. Otherwise, eventually, there may be a basis for him to be impeached.
If he does sell there will be a huge --really massive--tax penalty. But good point re conflicts in this case as indicating potential conflicts of interest in general. Big problem.
I absolutely agree with you. Who is going to stop him?

Trump will continue with his self-interest motivated dealings because there's no one to stop him. We are hostages for the next likely 8 years, as we have zero strong leaders on the other side who have a winning chance. Merry Christmas.

Ridiculous. Marvin Miller is probably among the top half dozen people of any era who had the greatest impact on baseball and he gets stiffed while an owner's lackey like Selig gets in? These two decisions deserve a replay.
If character counts toward admission to the Hall, then Steinbrenner will never get in.
I would vote Hall election for the fictional 'Big Stein' voiced by the unseen Larry David on Seinfeld.
If Big Stein had received the calzones promised by George,  the game would have turned out differently for the Yankees and for all of us as well
Great read, as always. Miss you, George.

This would work, though i think eight teams would be better. The odds that the best team in the country was not in the top 6 (or 8) rankings are very low, and that should be the question any committee or selection system should be primarily concerned with. A narrow loss late in the season (due to injuries, fluke, refs, whatever) could cause what would ultimately be the best team in the country (I.e. could beat all the others in a playoff) out of the top 4 ranked spots, but extremely unlikely they would be out of the top 8.
Last year, Alabama, Ohio State and Clemson all had a graduation rate in excess of 80 per cent.  Your comment seems to be sour grapes

Shamrock you are direct these jerks are not Christians but they run instutions that use religion to gain money and power. They must be outed for the frauds they are and that us what the article is about.

18 million jobs may not sound much in an economy with 145 million jobs, but the point is that these job losses are not distributed evenly across the country. The damage is mainly done in rural areas and small cities away from the coasts. Half the US population lives in rural areas or cities of less than 2 million people, and those are the areas that suffer most.

One industry that went to China was furniture manufacturing. The US produces a lot of hardwood lumber, and shipping that to China and then shipping the furniture back to America is expensive. The jobs were lost from small cities like Hickory, North Carolina, not New York or San Francisco. That is an industry that might come back to the US if we impose tariffs on China and other countries which run large trade surpluses with the US.

The "public" editor is really the paper's apologist. Allowing neo-Nazis to hide behind an anodyne name is DISHONEST.

The NYT's decision to sanitize what has happened to our country is to cooperate in the Trump/Bannon/neo-Nazi takeover. You are complicit.

You haven't been paying attention, have you? Just a couple of months prior to the election, a study reported that the NYTimes had carried more negative coverage of Hilary than of Trump.
Do try to keep up.

This is a great piece in its exposition of how the use of different words totally changes the tenor and political tilt of a news piece (e.g., "illegal immigrant" vs. "undocumented worker"). Somehow, the intellectual left and center (you know who you are) have failed for years to understand how effectively conservatives and Republicans have used these linguistic tools to influence people's emotions as well as their perceptions of "reality." We smart people need to do better.

I don't respect her opinion, and I'm not sure it IS her opinion. She whitewashes the NYT's insistence during the long campaign to enforce equivalency between Hillary's steadfastness in the face of thirty years of LIES and Donald's crooked dealings with suppliers, contractors, "students"/suckers, etc., etc.

She's trying to keep her JOB. Why would she join the rabble in insulting her bosses?
He's not that until after the inauguration and has no right to be identified that way until then. We have one president right now, Barack Obama, and his team is in the White House. Thankfully.
Christine -- interesting you should interpret "alt" as "alternative."  I thought of it as "extreme" as in the Latin alt for "high."
I'm not counting on them.  They are complicit in what has happened to our country.  Bannon/Trump own us now.  They are our masters.  What do you have that they cannot take?

geez, the media just started calling a blatant and repeated falsehood a lie. that's lovely. but it took about 18 months of Donald Trump's detached-from-reality campaign before it happened.

I know... the Times didn't spend much time on The Rent is Too Damned High guy either. But long after we saw him coming, the media was still viewing Donald through their entertainment lens and not informing readers.

As for the ult-right (sic), they are a despicable few who have been inflated by Trump's cluelessness.

They came very close here, but it's in the subjunctive (if I recall my grammar lessons correctly):
http://www.nytimes.com/2016/11/05/opinion/beyond-lying-donald-trumps-aut...

(The sentence is "Denouncing Trump as a liar, or describing him as merely entertaining, misses the point of authoritarian propaganda altogether. ")

And other newspapers have SAID they used the word, though they didn't:
http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/donald-trump-new-york-t...

...that was awarded to The Times for saying that “This is a lie, part of Mr. Trump’s pattern, stretching back many years, of disregard for indisputable facts."

Your comment is very helpful. It points out the delicacy with which media treat those with power. There's a sharp difference between calling one sentence a lie, and calling a man a "liar". The second brands the man as a type of person who lies all the time. After so very many lies for a full campaign season, that would not be an extreme step...but they won't take it.

What this issue and Ms. Spayd's column reveal is the tortuous backflips that the media go through when choosing the language they use when describing those in power, their extreme reluctance to come out and state their own very obvious conclusions about them, their...deference.

The right's preferred term for the most powerless in the community, "illegal immigrants", on the other hand, does get some use.

I know the reference to Hitler is overused (but you could choose any dictator.) The people who supported him (and there were many) were, in a word, WRONG. No matter the explanation, the descriptions, the analysis, the "fair reporting." They were, all of them, very wrong and it took a war to prove that so.

Being careful to be unbiased, with a person like the Orange Man, a person like any other dictator, is always a mistake. Likewise with his cronies and their "movement". There are times when a paper should be fair and unbiased to protect all opinions, as in a free country we expect. This is not one of those times. To anyone with eyes and ears, the people of the incoming administration are going to pulverize all social systems put into place since FDR, and do so with impunity. They will jeopardize the entire globe.

Ms. Spayd, unless you think these people are going to "do good things" for the country and the planet, worrying about words and how they are used is not some trivial pursuit by those who are holding the NYT to a hard line. Rather, it is absolutely necessary that this paper, the flagship for true democracy, be straight-forward and direct, even if other papers are not.

Words and terms are the only power we have. It cannot be that "balanced and fair reporting" of a thug, a thief and a control freak can co-exist. The descriptions of The Orange Man need to be blunt, hard-nosed and consistent. Explanations after the fact don't help. Nothing else is acceptable.

It is completely disingenuous for a newspaper to claim that battles won't be won "over a dictionary" or that "focusing on labels" is unproductive. Choosing the right words is literally your job. The NYT's obsession with "nuance" at the expense of the truth is increasingly absurd. Disguising white supremacy as populism is not a neutral choice; even if it were, there is nothing morally superior about neutrality in the face of bigotry. Trying to see the "gray" in the views of a racist, sexist xenophobe who is currently in a position of political power is not "braver than flat-out proclaiming someone a racist" - maybe the NYT needs to be reminded of how well appeasement worked out for Neville Chamberlain...

There is a name and there are essays written on the language of politics. The name is George Orwell and his essays explained how important language is in talking about politics. Then plutocrat William F Buckley Jr began to remind us of Alice's Adventures through the Looking Glass and her encounter with Humpty Dumpty who in a rather scornful tone said "When I use a word, it means exactly what I choose it to mean, neither more--- nor less."
Fortunately I have learned that in order to discuss politics with my conservative friends we had to spend hours discussing words and their meaning.

As is often the case, Liz tries to defuse an issue by making it trivial instead of fucusing on the problem. So apparently The Times is not sanitizing prejudice and bigotry by using the antiseptic term "alt-right" because of an internal memo defining the word in scathing terms.

The Times still has some clout, but supposing it actually controls usage in the English language is hubris. And the use of this term does convey a clinical distinction instead of abhorrence, whatever The Times may think.
